1164550931616165888.text: It's important to recognize that the burning of the Amazon may also be, in part, a consequence of the trade war with Chinahttps://twitter.com/CNN/status/1164386997634568194 …

1164552459030675461.text:
China's most pointed action on trade has arguably been ceasing imports of American soy. 

It's by far the biggest soybean importer and the U.S. and Brazil are by far the biggest exporters:https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2019-07-31/don-t-bank-on-china-buying-more-u-s-farm-goods …

1164570286399918080.text: Thanks David, this is excellent. The Cerrado - Amazon confusion is widespread. Size of Substitution effect is crucial to analysis. More context here:https://twitter.com/70sBachchan/status/1161622928779337728 …

1164553265175859200.text:
With Chinese imports from the U.S. drying up, and the prospect of more crops damaged by the midwest floods this year, demand from Brazil is soaring.

Traditionally the U.S. and Brazil exported roughly equal quantities of soy. This year the ratio should be 3:2 in Brazil's favour.pic.twitter.com/u0Ocx1Qy62

1164553961640087553.text: Despite what you might hear, soybeans are mostly not grown in the Amazon region in Brazil but in the cerrado, the savannah to the south of the rainforest. Former rainforest is more used for cattle ranching.

1164554701494345729.text: But land has multiple uses. One of the big things in Brazilian agribusiness at the moment is conversion -- turning marginal ranching and pasture country in the cerrado into croplands to grow soy.

1164555491202064384.text: That in itself releases more carbon because cropland soil is being tilled every year, making it less likely to lock up atmospheric carbon than pastures that are being trampled by livestock.

1164647882445729792.text: After reading your previous tweet, that was my first question, whether the expansion of soybean production was driving (some? many?) ranchers into rainforest areas they might have otherwise avoided.

1164650080101523456.text: To be honest, from what I've read it's still hard to tell what's happening in the fire-affected regions. We'll only know if they'll be turned to pastureland when the cattle move in. But, if credible reports of deliberate firing are correct, that's the likeliest explanation.

1164555804776624129.text: But the bigger risk is that ranchers are just displaced towards even more marginal land -- newly-cleared rainforest, for instance.

1164559358253862913.text:
IIRC, there's been a lot of hope over the past decade that this pastureland conversion could happen without deforestation. 

Brazil's pace of deforestation had fallen from a pace of about 3m hectares/year in the 1990s and early 2000s to more like 1m ha/yr over the past decade.

1164560131222200320.text: Deforestation is responsible for ~4 gigatonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions a year, not much less than the ~5gtCO2e from road transport (figures from 2010, may now be a bit outdated...)

1164560929586962433.text: In theory this should be some of the lowest-hanging fruit in terms of reducing global emissions. It doesn't involve rejigging energy systems on a global scale. It's essentially a land management and governance problem in about a dozen countries.

1164561736051019779.text: But it depends on all the political and economic drivers pointing in the right direction. Add a trade war and soybean shortage to Brazil's current government and those drivers all flip into the red. It's very bad news.

1164562475490037760.text:
There's a whole host of bad actors here and it's as much the fault of Xi Jinping and Jair Bolsonaro as Donald Trump. 

But it's notable to me that Trump's most damaging effects on climate have in many ways come via the trade war, not energy policy.

1164562973681049601.text: His attempts to revive the U.S. coal industry are foundering and carmakers are making deals with California to reject his weak fuel-efficiency regulations.

1164563209983938560.text: But China's industrial stimulus last year, as it sought to offset the effects of weaker trade, was the biggest driver of world emissions growth. And we're seeing the trade war's other effects in the Amazon today. (ends)
